An alternate etymology traces the Old French word to Late Latin laeticus (â€œof or relating to a semifree colonist in Gaulâ€), from Latin laetus (â€œa semi-free colonistâ€), from Gothic *ğŒ»ğŒ´ğ„ğƒ (*lÄ“ts) (attested in derivatives such as ğ†ğ‚ğŒ°ğŒ»ğŒ´ğ„ğƒ (fralÄ“ts)), from Proto-Germanic *lÄ“taz (â€œfreeman; bondsman, serfâ€), from *lÄ“tanÄ… (â€œto let; free; releaseâ€).

entries.meaning: Sovereign; independent; having authority or right to allegiance.
Serving an independent sovereign or master; bound by a feudal tenure; obliged to be faithful and loyal to a superior, such as a vassal to his lord; faithful.
examples: a liege man; a liege subject

entries.meaning: A free and independent person; specifically, a lord paramount; a sovereign.
(in full liege lord) A king or lord.
The subject of a sovereign or lord; a liegeman.
